journal-meta.journal-title: Proceedings of the Institution of Mechanical Engineers, Part C: Journal of Mechanical Engineering Science

title-group.article-title: Nonlinear vibration analysis of protein microtubules in cytosol conveying fluid based on nonlocal elasticity theory using differential quadrature method

article-meta.aff: 1Department of Mechanical Engineering, Faculty of Engineering, University of Kashan, Kashan, I.R. Iran
2Institute of Nanoscience and Nanotechnology, University of Kashan, Kashan, I.R. Iran

author-notes.corresp: A Ghorbanpour Arani, Department of Mechanical Engineering, Faculty of Engineering, University of Kashan, Kashan, I.R. Iran. Email: aghorban@kashanu.ac.ir; a_ghorbanpour@yahoo.com

abstract.p: In this article, nonlinear vibration of protein microtubules in cytosol with internal flow is studied. Based on the Euler–Bernoulli beam theory with von Kármán nonlinearity type and using Hamilton’s principle, the equations of motion for fluid-conveying microtubules are derived. The size effect is taken into account using Eringen’s nonlocal elasticity theory; moreover, the effect of an elastic surrounding filament network and the surface traction of cytosol are studied. The governing differential equations for vibration response of microtubules are solved using the differential quadrature method. The nonlinear frequency response of microtubules, considering the effect of microtubule properties, size effect, the surrounding elastic media, and the fluid motion are reported in this article. It has been found that the effect of nonlocal parameter on the vibration behavior and instability of the embedded microtubule conveying fluid are significant. In this regard, we need to point out that the critical flow velocity for a range of nonlocality parameter from 0 to 2 nm varies between 41 and 47 m/s, which should be avoided due to instability of the microtubule system. Therefore, they should be taken into account in the design of nano/micro-devices for measuring density of a fluid, such as drugs flowing through such microtubules, with great applications in biomechanics.

sec.title: Introduction
sec.p: A unique ability of eukaryotic cells is their ability to adopt different shapes, coordinate these shapes, and direct their movements via various cytoskeletal functions. Microtubules (MTs) are one of the three major kinds of classes of filaments in structures such as complex networks of polymers1 which serve vital roles in many functions of cells such as separating chromosomes in length of mitosis, facilitating inter-cell long movements of proteins and organisms, providing mechanical resistance for keeping a cell, and supporting motor proteins in order to produce the needed power for cell deformation and motility. Additionally, a fundamental understanding of MT dynamics could inform anti-cancer drug designers.2

Since most of these roles are dependent on mechanical properties, they need MTs which have enough resistance against bending in large scales and also have considerable elasticity at smaller scales. So, the study of MT mechanical properties are important in stating their biological functions. It is also a great help in designing molecular shuttle and force probes operating at the piconewton level3 which is a technology key to the continuously diminishing scale at which lab-on-a-chip tools are being designed. MT biological functions are greatly dependent on their mechanical properties. Recently, the structural aspects of MTs and the results of their mechanical behavior have been presented.4 The first accurate measurements of the flexural rigidity of MTs by thermal analysis were reported by Gittes et al.5 and they found that for MTs, even small convective currents cause bending as large as a thermal bending. MT bending and breaking in living fibroblast cells were presented by Odde et al.6 who found that the curvature dependence of MT breaking could serve a number of cellular functions. Tuszynski et al.7 discussed the results of homology modeling and resulting calculation of key structural and physical properties for close to 300 tubulin sequences. Finally, they have explained how tubulin sequence diversity arose in evolution, giving rise to its particular phylogeny and how it may be used in cell- and tissue-specific expression including embryonic development. Kalweit and Drikakis8 presented a review of multiscale simulation strategies for the modeling of micro- and nanoscale flows. They focused on hybrid molecular-continuum methods and reviewed different coupling strategies, including geometrical decomposition in conjunction material state and flux coupling, and discussed briefly about different applications of these methods. Also, Kalweit and Drikakis9 investigated the behavior of the density profile of fluidic material confined by a force field, as it occurs across molecular-continuum mechanics boundaries in multiscale, hybrid molecular-continuum simulations.

Moreover, the importance of biopolymer structural study and their important role in the progress of materials science have been discussed by Keten et al.10 In their study, silk, which is a biological protein fiber, has been examined. In order to investigate the mechanical properties of MTs, the continuum isotropic (Euler–Bernoulli) elastic beam model applies widely the analysis of one-dimensional deformation of MTs (as the examination of column-like buckling by Kurachi et al.11 or beam-like vibration by Pampaloni et al.12 in which flexural rigidity of MTs and Young’s modulus have been studied).

Micro/nano-beams are also one of the main structures used in micro-electronic–mechanical systems and nanotechnology which are applied in sensors, actuators, fluid storage, fluid transport, and drug delivery.13 In these cases, the thickness of the beam structure is in the range of micro- or even nanometer.14

Recently, the inside diameter of the circular microtubes was considered to range from 1 to 100 µm by Rinaldi et al.15 It was reported that microtubes/microbeams containing an internal fluid flow exist in a class of microresonators.16 Therefore, it is not surprising that the topic of fluid transport through beams (or tubes) is now of considerable interest for potential micro- and nano-fluidic device applications.17 From the other side, the carbon nanotubes embedded in polymer and metals have a number of interesting applications.18 One of these interesting functions is the pipes with internal fluid flow at nanoscale which can be used for drug delivery at the molecule scale. The existence of internal fluid flow in nanostructure is different from macro structure, since at the nanoscale, atomic interactions between structure and flow, microscopic properties of flow such as the velocity, density, etc., are not ignorable.19 Recently, different atomistic-based techniques, such as MT molecular dynamic simulation, have been developed for modeling the dynamic behavior of nanotubes and their conveying-flow interaction. Although continuum-based elasticity models are expensive, they are applied in nano-mechanics modeling, structural deformation and stability, vibration, and heat transfer. The results of this method have a great accordance with many results obtained from atomistic-based studies. These close results show that continuum-based modeling can be applied in nano- and micro-scales. This method can also be used for linear and nonlinear vibration response of embedded nanotubes.20

In this study, an attempt has been made for the first time to use Euler–Bernoulli beam theory to examine the vibration response of MTs that are embedded inside the surrounding cytosol and have an internal fluid flow. In this method, the effects of small scale and also those of internal flow and viscoelastic forces, which are due to the surrounding cytosol, on MT amplitude and frequency, are considered. The results of this study is hoped to be useful in the design and manufacturing of nano/micro-devices in advanced medical applications using drugs as the flowing fluid in MTs, thereby predicting blood clot formation, warning heart attacks, and carrying oxygen or other gases, as well as for delivery of specific drugs to specific location or cells in the body (e.g. tumors or cancerous cells).

sec.title: Governing equations
sec.p:
Consider a MT embedded in a viscoelastic medium with elastic modulus Ec and viscosity μ (including the effects of the surrounding filament network and cytosol), as illustrated in Figure 1. The MT is modeled as a cylinder with infinite length and radius R0 with bending rigidity EI. Assume that deformations of MTs are in the x and z planes and the displacements are denoted along the x-, y-, and z-directions by U, V, and W, respectively. Figure 1.
Schematic of an embedded MT.
MT: microtubule.

Based on the nonlocal elasticity theory of Eringen,21 the stress tensor at a specific point of a body depends on the strain tensor at all points on the body. Therefore, the nonlocal stress tensor is (1)(1-τ∇2)σijnl=σijlσijl=Cijklɛijτ=(e0a)2 where (e0a)2 is the nonlocal parameter and σl the local stress tensor at that point relating to the strain tensor by the Hooke’s law.
The normal resultant force and the bending moment are therefore defined as (2)Nxx=∫σxxnldAMxx=∫σxxnlzdA

The normal resultant force Nxx is obtained by integrating the nonlocal stress tensors σxxnl along the thickness in the z-direction. The bending moment Mxx is also obtained by integrating the stress tensor multiplied by z-direction.

According to the Euler–Bernoulli theory which has no limitation on small-scale effect, we are using the Euler–Bernoulli beam theory for displacement field which is written as follows (3)u(x,z,t)=u(x,t)-z∂w∂xv(x,z,t)=0w(x,z,t)=w(x,t)
The nonlinear strain–displacement relationship is written using von Kármán equation as (4)ɛxx=∂u∂x+12(∂w∂x)2=∂u∂x+12(∂w∂x)2-z∂2w∂x2

To obtain the equations of motion, the Hamilton’s principle, which is obtained from the energy method, can be applied. The total energy is written as (5)Π=K-U+V where K, U, and V are kinetic energy, strain energy, and work done due to external forces, respectively.
By applying the virtual work method in Hamilton’s principle (6)δ∫t0tΠdt=0 Therefore (7)δ∫t0t(K-U+V)dt=0

The kinetic energy K in Euler–Bernoulli beam conveying-fluid flow and its variation δK can be expressed as follows (8)K=∫vρ2(∂ui∂t)2dv⇒δK=∫vρ(∂ui∂t)(∂δui∂t)dvδK=∫vρ(∂u∂t)(∂δu∂t)dv+∫vρf(v2+(DwDt)2)dvδK=∫z[(ρAu'δu'+ρI∂w'∂x∂δw'∂x) +ρf(v2+(DwDt)2)]dz
Also, the strain energy U and its variation δU may be expressed as (9)U=12∫vσijɛijdVδU=∫vσijδɛijdV=∫[(σxxδɛxx)]dVδU=∫[σxx[∂δu∂x+∂w∂x∂δw∂x-z∂2δw∂x2]]dVδU=∫z[Nxx[∂δu∂x+∂w∂x∂δw∂x]-Mxx[∂2δw∂x2]]dz

The work done in equation of motion includes the elastic surrounding filament network force and surface traction of the cytosol and is denoted as (10)V=∫vfiuidVδV=∫vfiδuidV=∫[fxδu+fyδv+qδw]dVδV=∫z-Fδwdz

By applying the Hamilton’s principle to obtain the equation of motion of the MT, we have (11)∂Nxx∂x=ρA∂2u∂t2+ρfA∂2u∂t2 (12)∂2Mxx∂x2+∂∂x(Nxx∂w∂x)-F=ρA∂2w∂t2 -ρI∂4w∂x2∂t2+ρfA∂2w∂t2+2ρfAVf∂2w∂x∂t +ρfAVf2∂2w∂x2 where ρ is the density of the MT, ρf the density of the cytosol, and I the inertia moment of the MT.

Stress resultant equation can be written in terms of displacements using stress–strain relationship (equation (1)), nonlinear strain–displacement relationship (equation (4)), and stress resultant equation (equation (2)) as follows (13)N-(e0a)2∂2N∂x2=EA(∂u∂x+12(∂w∂x)2) (14)M-(e0a)2∂2M∂x2=-EI(∂2w∂x2) where I and A are defined as follows (15)A=2πrhI=πhr3

Substituting equations (13) and (14) into equations of motion (equations (11) and (12)), the governing equation in terms of displacements yields the following differential equations as (16)EA(∂2u∂x2+∂w∂x∂2w∂x2)=ρA∂2u∂t2-(e0a)2ρA∂4u∂x2∂t2 +ρfA∂2u∂t2-(e0a)2ρfA∂4u∂x2∂t2 (17)-EI(∂4w∂x4)+EA(∂2u∂x2+∂w∂x∂2w∂x2)(∂w∂x) +EA(∂u∂x+12(∂w∂x)2)(∂2w∂x2)-F+(e0a)2∂2F∂x2 =ρA∂2w∂t2-(e0a)2ρA∂4w∂x2∂t2-ρI∂4w∂x2∂t2 +(e0a)2ρI∂6w∂x4∂t2+ρfA∂2w∂t2-(e0a)2ρfA∂4w∂x2∂t2 -ρfI∂4w∂x2∂t2+(e0a)2ρfI∂6w∂x4∂t2 +2ρfAVf∂2w∂x∂t+ρfAVf2∂2w∂x2

The continuity condition requires that the cytosol move with the same radial velocity as that of the MTs at the boundary r = R (radius of the MT). In addition, due to the existence of the slip layer on the surface of MTs, the free slip boundary condition is enforced at the MT–cytosol interface. The friction between the MTs and cytosol is assumed to be zero. Furthermore, such a slip layer is so thin that its momentum and angular momentum of inertia can be safely neglected. Therefore, according to Figure 2, we consider that the MT conveying fluid is subjected to external forces including the elastic surrounding filament network force and surface traction of the cytosol, which can be expressed as follows (18)F=ξw+πμη∂w∂t where (19)ξ=2.7Ecη=(1-q4)lnq-12q2+2q4+10(q4-1)lnq+2q2-q4-1q=R0R1 where Ec is the Young’s modulus of the surrounding filament network, R0 the radius of MT; and R1 the distance of the center line to the position where the viscous flow of the cytosol region vanishes.22 Figure 2.
MT conveying fluid under external forces.
MT: microtubule.

Substituting equation (18) into equation of motion (equation (17)) yields the governing equation in terms of displacements as follows (20)-EI(∂4w∂x4)+32EA(∂w∂x)2(∂2w∂x2)-ξw-πμη∂w∂t +(e0a)2ξ∂2w∂x2+(e0a)2πμη∂3w∂x2∂t=(ρ+ρf)A∂2w∂t2 -(e0a)2(ρ+ρf)A∂4w∂x2∂t2+2ρfAVf∂2w∂x∂t +ρfAVf2∂2w∂x2
In order to solve the time derivatives of equation (20), the dynamic displacement vector w is considered as w(x,t)=w(x)eiωt.
It is convenient to introduce the following dimensionless parameters as (21)W=whγ=12ρfl2Eh2Vf2α=12ξl2Eh3X=xlθ=2ρflVfh12E(ρ+ρf)β=πμηh212E(ρ+ρf)λ=e0alT=tt0t0=12(ρ+ρf)l4Eh2
Therefore, the governing equation in a dimensionless form is written as follows (22)(∂4W∂X4)-18(∂W∂X)2(∂2W∂X2)+αl2(W)+βl2(∂W∂T) -τα(∂2W∂X2)-τβ(∂3W∂X2∂T)=-(∂2W∂T2) +λ2(∂4W∂X2∂T2)-θ(∂2W∂X∂T)-γ(∂2W∂X2)
The boundary conditions for bending variables involve specifying one element of each of the following pairs (23)6(∂W∂X)3-(∂3W∂X3)=0orW∂2W∂X2=0or∂W∂X
In this article, we have considered the boundary conditions of simply supported; therefore, for MTs of length L, w = 0 and M = 0 at x = 0, L.

sec.title: Method of solution
sec.p: It is evident that the governing equation includes nonlinear terms and should be solved using a numerical procedure. The method used in this study is differential quadrature method (DQM). In this method, the differential equations change into algebraic equations of first order and weighting coefficients. In other words, the partial derivatives of a function (say w here) are approximated by a specific variable (named x), at discontinuous points in the domain (0<x<L) as a set of weighting series, and its amount represented by the function itself at that point and other points throughout the domain.

The expressed approximate function may be written in the general form as follows (24)f(n)(xi)=∑j=1NAij(n)f(xj) where, in general, f(x) is the function and Aij the weighting coefficients which are defined as the following equations (25)Aij(1)=M(xi)(xi-xj)M(xj)Aij(n)=n(Aij(1)Aiin-1-Aijn-1xi-xj)Aii(n)=-∑j=1NAij(n)
M is Lagrangian operator which is defined as (26)M(xi)=Πk=1N(xi-xk)
A proper set of grid points in the form of cosine relation (or the Gauss–Lobatto–Chebyshev) is introduced as follows (27)xi=12[1-cos(πiN)]
In this study, unequally spaced grid points in conjunction with DQM are used to evaluate the weighting coefficients.

The standard DQM form of this governing equation (equation (22)) may be written as follows (28)∑j=1NAij(4)W(xj)-18∑j=1NAij(2)W(xj)(∑j=1NAij(1)W(xj))2 +αl2W(xi)+βl2W·(xi)-τα∑j=1NAij(2)W(xj) -τβ∑j=1NAij(3)W·(xj)+W··(xi)-τl2∑j=1NAij(2)W··(xj) +γ∑j=1NAij(2)W(xj)+θ∑j=1NAij(1)W·(xj)=0

sec.title: Results and discussion
sec.p: The continuity condition requires that the cytosol move with the same radial velocity as that of the MTs at the boundary r = R (radius of the MT). In addition, due to the existence of the slip layer on the surface of MTs, the free slip boundary condition is enforced at the MT–cytosol interface. The friction between MTs and cytosol is assumed to be zero. Furthermore, such a slip layer is so thin that its momentum and angular momentum of inertial can be safely neglected.
In numerical computations, the characteristics of the MTs are assumed as follows E=1GPaρ=1.47gcm3μ=695×10-6h=1.6nm,e0a=3nm,R0=10.7nm

Assume that the boundary conditions are simply supported MT with average radius R0, Young’s modulus E, mass density per unit volume ρ, equivalent thickness h, nonlocality e0a, and viscosity of cytosol μ.23
Considering the above assumptions, the aspect ratio is also assumed to be equal to 300 and the axial forces are neglected.

For assuring the accuracy of the results obtained by numerical method of DQM, the internal flow will be equal to zero and the results are compared to Shen (Figure 3).23 This figure showed that the numerical result by DQM method is same as that of Shen.23 Figure 3.
Comparison between results of Shen23 with DQM.
DQM: differential quadrature method.

The equation of motion (28) is solved using DQM. The ratio of the nonlinear-to-linear frequency and the corresponding maximum vibration amplitude to thickness, wmaxh, are studied and the effect of various parameters, such as internal flow velocity, the elastic coefficient of the surrounding filament network, density ratio, viscosity of cytosol, and aspect ratio, are considered.

In order to examine the effects of viscosity coefficient of the surrounding cytosol on the vibrational behavior of MTs, two cases are considered. In the first case, the amount of elasticity coefficient of the surrounding fiber network ξ is assumed as zero and in the second, the maximum amount for ξ(ξ = 2700) is examined. The resultant conclusions are shown in Figures 4 and 5. Figure 4.
Effect of viscosity of cytosol on nonlinear amplitude–frequency response curves for MT for ξ = 0.
MT: microtubule.
Figure 5.
Effect of viscosity of cytosol on nonlinear amplitude–frequency response curves for MT for ξ = 2700.
MT: microtubule.

As shown in Figure 4, for ξ=0, by increasing the amount of viscosity coefficient to η = 1.5, the amount of vibrational frequency ratio increases at first, but after that, by increasing the amount of viscosity coefficient (η = 5.5), the frequency ratio decreases, which is an indication for a critical viscosity coefficient.

In Figure 5, the effect of viscosity coefficient in the presence of an elastic surrounding filament network force can be observed. According to the figure, it can be observed that in this case, by increasing the amount of viscosity coefficient, the amount of vibration frequency ratio has a diminutive increase, which states that in presence of an elastic surrounding filament network, the effect of viscosity coefficient on the ratio of nonlinear-to-linear frequency is diminutive, and in this case, linear models can also be used.
While in the absence of an elastic surrounding filament network force, the effect of viscosity coefficient of the surrounding cytosol on the nonlinear vibration behavior of MTs is meaningful.

Figures 6 and 7 show the effect of the elastic surrounding filament network force on MT vibrational behavior. Figure 6.
Effect of elastic coefficient of the surrounding filament network on nonlinear amplitude–frequency response curves for MT for η = 0.
MT: microtubule.
Figure 7.
Effect of elastic coefficient of the surrounding filament network on nonlinear amplitude–frequency response curves for MT for η = 5.5.

In Figure 6, the changes of the vibration frequency ratio to amplitude by increasing the elastic surrounding filament network force and without considering viscosity coefficient can be seen, and in Figure 7, these changes have been drawn in the presence of the critical amount of viscosity coefficient η = 5.5. As it can be observed from both figures, by increasing the elastic surrounding filament network force, the ratio of frequency decreases, so that in the maximum case, the elastic surrounding filament network force (ξ = 2700), the ratio of nonlinear-to-linear frequency is equal to one and the effect of nonlinear model can be neglected since the presence of the elastic surrounding filament network force will cause the stability of the MT vibrational behavior.

Figure 8 demonstrates the vibrational responses of MTs with changes in aspect ratio. Since the existence of the elastic surrounding filament network force causes that vibrational responses leads to a linear model, for examining the effect of aspect ratio (L/R) on MT nonlinear behavior, the amount of ξ is considered as zero. Figure 8.
Effects of aspect ratio on nonlinear amplitude–frequency response curves for MT.
MT: microtubule.

It is shown in Figure 8 that increasing the aspect ratio increases the dependence of the frequency ratio; in other words, for high aspect ratios, the nonlinear effects are profound, and so, the high increase of aspect ratio is harmful for the stability of the structure.

Another parameter that can affect the amplitude frequency is the density ratio of the MT to the cytosol. In this part, the changes of density ratio have been drawn from 0.1 to 0.6. Figure 9 demonstrates increase in the frequency ratio with increase in the density ratio. This increase is as long as the density ratio reaches the critical value, which is 0.6. This critical ratio is that which causes a fall in the frequency ratio and instability. Figure 9.
Effects of density ratio on nonlinear amplitude–frequency response curves for MT.
MT: microtubule.
In other words, it can be said that the flow density has a critical value where the vibrational behavior of the MT becomes instable. Here, the critical density ratio is 0.6.

The last effective parameter in MT amplitude–frequency responses is the effect of nonlocality. As it can be observed from Figure 10, increase in the nonlocality coefficient causes an increase in the frequency ratio. Figure 10.
Effects of nonlocality on nonlinear amplitude–frequency response curves for MT.
MT: microtubule.

According to what is seen in Figure 11, it is found that the frequency decreases with increasing internal flow velocities. It is also shown that the MTs will become unstable by divergence at a critical flow velocity. Furthermore, we can see that in this case by increasing the amount of radius to the MT length the frequency decreases. In other words, the reduction in MT diameter leads to an increase in frequency. Figure 11.
Effects of aspect ratio on velocity–frequency response curves for MT.
MT: microtubule.

Figure 12 presents the influence of a nonlocal parameter, e0a, on the natural frequency versus flow velocity. For zero natural frequency, MT becomes unstable and the corresponding fluid velocity is called the critical flow velocity. Figure 12 indicates that in general the critical flow velocity decreases with increasing e0a and also natural frequency becomes lower when e0a is increased. However, it is shown that the influence of a nonlocal parameter on the vibration behavior and instability of the embedded conveying-fluid MT is significant. Figure 12.
Effects of nonlocality on critical flow velocity.

sec.title: Conclusions
sec.p: In this article, Euler–Bernoulli beam theory has been presented for examining and studying the MT vibrational responses which include the effects of small scale.

Using Hamilton’s principle, the governing motion of equation on MT in the surrounding cytosol has been achieved. The governing differential equation was solved using DQM numerical method. The vibrational behavior of MT with internal conveying flow and in the presence of exerted forces of the surrounding cytosol was examined again using nonlocal Euler–Bernoulli beam theory. The effect of viscoelastic forces, flow velocity, aspect ratio and density ratio and the effect of nonlocality on amplitude–frequency are studied, and it was demonstrated that there is a critical fluid velocity and also fluid density which causes MT dynamic instability in the surrounding cytosol. The findings of this study may be used in advanced medical applications of smart nano/micro-devices for predicting blood clot formation, warning heart attacks, and carrying oxygen or other gases, as well as for specific delivery of drugs to specific location or cells (e.g. tumors or cancerous cells).

sec.title: Funding
sec.p: This work was supported by University of Kashan [grant number 65475/3].
